image.altText: Donald Trump, holding an umbrella in the rain, speaks to reporters at an airport.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump has pleaded not guilty after being indicted on charges related to his conduct in the 2020 presidential election. Follow our live updates.

title.children: Trump claims he's being 'persecuted' after pleading not guilty to 2020 election interference charges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A lawyer who supported Donald Trump's attempts to overturn his 2020 election defeat has been charged with illegally accessing voting machines in Michigan, just hours before the former president was due to appear court. Stefanie Lambert Junttila, who along with other Trump allies tried to reverse Trump's defeat to US President Joe Biden in Michigan, was charged with accessing, tampering with and undue possession of voting machines in the state. Ms Lambert is the third person charged in Michigan this week after a special prosecutor in that state reviewed allegations that Trump allies illegally accessed voting machines after the 2020 election. Two other Republicans, former Michigan attorney general candidate Matt DePerno, and Daire Rendon, a former state representative, made their initial court appearances on Tuesday in connection with the case. All three were named last year by the state's attorney general in an investigation of a scheme to access voting tabulators.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump ally charged over vote machine tampering hours before former president's court appearance

children.content: A lawyer who supported Donald Trump's attempts to overturn his 2020 election defeat has been charged with
illegally accessing voting machines
in Michigan, just hours before the former president was due to appear court.
Stefanie Lambert Junttila

, who along with other Trump allies tried to reverse Trump's defeat to US President Joe Biden in Michigan, was charged with accessing, tampering with and undue possession of voting machines in the state.

props.alt: Stefabie Lambert sits and listens in court (FILE PHOTO).

children.content: Stefanie Lambert Junttila has been charged.
(Reuters)

Ms Lambert is the third person charged in Michigan this week after a special prosecutor in that state reviewed allegations that Trump allies illegally accessed voting machines after the 2020 election.
Two other Republicans, former Michigan attorney general candidate
Matt DePerno
, and
Daire Rendon
, a former state representative, made their initial court appearances on Tuesday in connection with the case.
All three were named last year by the state's attorney general in an investigation of a scheme to access voting tabulators.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan has been in court covering today's events and spoke to News Breakfast a short time ago. Jade: [Donald Trump] left the complex very quickly. He gave a brief statement before he boarded the plane and left Washington, DC. He repeated the arguments that we have heard from him before … He also criticised Washington itself, the city that he was forced to return to, and this courthouse being just down the road from where the January 6 attack unfolded at the US Capitol. His lawyers have said they would try to have this case moved out of Washington. They argued this city, this district, voted overwhelmingly for Joe Biden in 2020 and he wouldn't get a fair trial here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump's lawyers have indicated they will try to have the case moved out of Washington

children.content: The ABC's North America bureau chief
Jade Macmillan
has been in court covering today's events and spoke to News Breakfast a short time ago.
Jade:
[Donald Trump] left the complex very quickly. He gave a brief statement before he boarded the plane and left Washington, DC.

He repeated the arguments that we have heard from him before … He also criticised Washington itself, the city that he was forced to return to, and this courthouse being just down the road from where the January 6 attack unfolded at the US Capitol.
His lawyers have said they would try to have this case moved out of Washington. They argued
this city, this district, voted overwhelmingly for Joe Biden in 2020 and he wouldn't get a fair trial here.

props.alt: A court sketch of Donald Trump in court.

children.content: A court sketch from today's hearing
(Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The former US president described the 2020 election interference charges against him as the "persecution" of a political opponent, and claimed he was ahead of Joe Biden in the 2024 presidential race. The ABC's Chloe Ross is in Washington: Chloe: Mr Trump is the overwhelming frontrunner to claim the Republican nomination for president. However, contrary to his claim, a recent poll had him tied with Mr Biden in a hypothetical rematch at 43 percent support.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: WATCH: Trump speaks after arraignment over 2020 election interference claims

children.content: The former US president described the 2020 election interference charges against him as the "persecution" of a political opponent, and claimed he was ahead of Joe Biden in the 2024 presidential race.
The ABC's
Chloe Ross
is in Washington:
Chloe:
Mr Trump is the overwhelming frontrunner to claim the Republican nomination for president. However, contrary to his claim,
a recent poll had him tied with Mr Biden in a hypothetical rematch at 43 percent support.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's government says it needs to spend more on its military and strengthen  ties with countries in the Indo-Pacific to help meet the challenges of great power rivalry and climate change. Launching the country's first national security strategy, Defence Minister Andrew Little says New Zealand faces more geostrategic challenges than it has in decades. "An increasingly powerful China is using all its instruments of national power in ways that can pose challenges to existing international rules and norms," reads one policy document. Another document reportedly says Chinese state-sponsored actors had exploited cyber vulnerabilities in ways that undermined New Zealand's security. Little told media that New Zealand spent roughly 1 per cent of its GDP on defence and that this would need to increase. The wide-ranging review also prioritised deeper defence ties with New Zealand's only ally, Australia, and closer links to other partners in the region, including the US.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NZ says it needs to spend more on its military amid an 'increasingly powerful China'

props.alt: A soldier carrying a gun and water bottle, standing in a forest while wealing miiltary uniform camo and helmet

children.content: (ABC Capricornia: Chrissy Arthur)
New Zealand's government says it
needs to spend more on its military and strengthen  ties with countries in the Indo-Pacific
to help meet the challenges of great power rivalry and climate change.
Launching the country's first national security strategy, Defence Minister Andrew Little says New Zealand faces more geostrategic challenges than it has in decades.
"An increasingly powerful China is using all its instruments of national power in ways that can pose challenges to existing international rules and norms," reads one policy document.
Another document reportedly says Chinese state-sponsored actors had exploited cyber vulnerabilities in ways that undermined New Zealand's security.
Little told media that New Zealand spent roughly 1 per cent of its GDP on defence and that this would need to increase.
The wide-ranging review also prioritised deeper defence ties with New Zealand's only ally, Australia, and closer links to other partners in the region, including the US.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The number of Australians reaching out for support from homelessness services spiked 7.5 per cent between December 2022 and March this year, analysis from Homelessness Australia has found. The majority of people were experiencing financial stress or issues from the housing crisis. "The increases in rent and the record-low vacancy rates are driving more people to homeless services," Homelessness Australia chief executive Kate Colvin tells AAP. "There's been such significant increases in people coming through the door that they're not even able to necessarily record everyone who's seeking help." According to the report, Queensland had a 12.9 per cent rise in homelessness service use, the largest increase in any Australian state, followed by Western Australia (11.1 per cent) and NSW (10.2 per cent).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Report finds more Australians are reaching out to homelessness services

props.alt: A person in a hoodie and trackpants sitting under a tree in a park

children.content: (ABC News: Danielle Bonica)
The number of Australians reaching out for support from homelessness services
spiked 7.5 per cent between December 2022 and March this year
, analysis from Homelessness Australia has found.
The majority of people were experiencing financial stress or issues from the housing crisis.
"The increases in rent and the record-low vacancy rates are driving more people to homeless services," Homelessness Australia chief executive Kate Colvin tells AAP.
"There's been such significant increases in people coming through the door that they're not even able to necessarily record everyone who's seeking help."
According to the report,
Queensland had a 12.9 per cent rise in homelessness service use, the largest increase in any Australian state
, followed by Western Australia (11.1 per cent) and NSW (10.2 per cent).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two US Navy sailors have been arrested and accused of providing sensitive military information to China — including details on wartime exercises, naval operations and critical technical material, federal officials say. As The Associated Press reports, officials at a news conference in San Diego declined to specify whether the sailors were aware of each other's actions. But they did say cases exemplify China's brazenness in trying to obtain insight into US military operations. "Through the alleged crimes committed by these defendants, sensitive military information ended up in the hands of the People's Republic of China," US Attorney Randy Grossman says. The arrested sailors are Jinchao Wei, a 22-year-old born in China, who was allegedly approached by a Chinese intelligence officer while he was applying to become a naturalised US citizen. The other is sailor Wenheng Zhao, 26, who officials allege conspired to collect bribes from a Chinese intelligence officer in exchange for US naval exercise plans, operational orders and photos and videos of electrical systems.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two US Navy sailors have been charged with sharing military information with China

props.alt: An American Navy ship carrying helicopters and displaying an American flag, sails in the ocean in front of another smaller ship

children.content: (US Navy: Brian M. Wilbur)
Two US Navy sailors have been arrested and accused of providing sensitive military information to China — including
details on wartime exercises, naval operations and critical technical material
, federal officials say.
As The Associated Press reports, officials at a news conference in San Diego declined to specify whether the sailors were aware of each other's actions.
But they did say cases exemplify China's brazenness in trying to obtain insight into US military operations.
"Through the alleged crimes committed by these defendants, sensitive military information ended up in the hands of the People's Republic of China," US Attorney Randy Grossman says.

props.alt: Three men in suits and ties speaking from a podium during a press conference, in front of an American flag

children.content: (AP: Meg McLaughlin/The San Diego Union-Tribune)
The arrested sailors are
Jinchao Wei, a 22-year-old born in China
, who was allegedly approached by a Chinese intelligence officer while he was applying to become a naturalised US citizen.
The other is sailor
Wenheng Zhao, 26
, who officials allege conspired to collect bribes from a Chinese intelligence officer in exchange for US naval exercise plans, operational orders and photos and videos of electrical systems.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In a widely-anticipated decision, the Bank of England raised rates by 0.25 percentage points. That puts UK borrowing costs at a 15-year high, with the BoE's key rate hitting 5.25 per cent. "The latest hike represents a slowdown in the pace of tightening following a 50 basis point hike at the BoE's last meeting," St George economists noted. "Comments from BoE officials following the decision continued to suggest inflation risks are skewed to the upside, even though the committee’s labour force and growth forecasts were revised lower." BoE governor Andrew Bailey said it was too early to start speculating about any rate cuts to come. "I don't think it is time to declare it's all over… "We might need to raise interest rates again but that's not certain," he told a press conference.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bank of England hikes interest rates, as expected

children.content: In a widely-anticipated decision, the
Bank of England raised rates by 0.25 percentage points
That puts UK borrowing costs at
a 15-year high,
with the BoE's key rate hitting 5.25 per cent.
"The latest hike represents a slowdown in the pace of tightening following a 50 basis point hike at the BoE's last meeting," St George economists noted.
"Comments from BoE officials following the decision continued to suggest inflation risks are skewed to the upside, even though the committee’s labour force and growth forecasts were revised lower."
BoE governor Andrew Bailey
said it was too early to start speculating about any rate cuts to come.
"I don't think it is time to declare it's all over…
"We might need to raise interest rates again but that's not certain," he told a press conference.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We'll get a closely-watched update from the Reserve Bank later this morning to finish off the week. The RBA's quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy will be released at 11:30am AEST, after the central bank left rates on hold on Tuesday. It will contain the latest economic forecasts. In Tuesday's post-meeting statement, governor Philip Lowe said inflation was expected to be around 3.25 per cent by the end of next year, and back between 2-3 per cent by late 2025. NAB's head of FX strategy Ray Attrill notes that the forecasts will be based on the assumed path of the cash rate prior to the August meeting, based on economist forecasts and market pricing — "the former encompassing a consensus view for at least one more rate rise in the cycle and the latter the best part of one." Since Tuesday, a number of economists have changed their forecasts — CBA and Westpac now say the cash rate has peaked at 4.1 per cent, while ANZ has maintained that call as well.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA's latest forecasts to be released later today

children.content: We'll get a closely-watched update from the Reserve Bank later this morning to finish off the week.
The
RBA's quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy
will be released at 11:30am AEST, after the central bank left rates on hold on Tuesday.
It will contain the latest economic forecasts.
In Tuesday's post-meeting statement, governor Philip Lowe said inflation was expected to be around 3.25 per cent by the end of next year, and back between 2-3 per cent by late 2025.
NAB's head of FX strategy Ray Attrill
notes that the forecasts will be
based on the assumed path of the cash rate prior
to the August meeting
, based on economist forecasts and market pricing — "the former encompassing a consensus view for at least one more rate rise in the cycle and the latter the best part of one."
Since Tuesday, a number of economists have changed their forecasts —
CBA and Westpac now say the cash rate has peaked at 4.1 per cent
, while ANZ has maintained that call as well.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Stephanie Chalmers here to take you through all the market news and moves of the day. ASX futures are pointing slightly lower at the moment, so we could see local stocks dip at the open. That's after overseas markets ended in the red. In the US, earnings season continued with some upside surprises for technology names. Amazon shares have surged in after-hours trading, after reporting higher-than-expected profit and sales. Growth in its cloud computing division Amazon Web Services improved after slowing in recent quarters. Apple's profit also beat Wall Street forecasts, but iPhone sales missed expectations. And the Australian-founded software firm Atlassian's revenue came in ahead of estimates, sending its shares up in extended trade. We'll bring you more throughout the session so stay with us this Friday!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets down, US tech earnings surprise to upside

children.content: Good morning,
Stephanie Chalmers
here to take you through all the market news and moves of the day.
ASX futures are pointing slightly lower at the moment, so we
could see local stocks dip at the open
That's after overseas markets ended in the red.
In the US, earnings season continued with some upside surprises for technology names.
Amazon shares have surged in after-hours trading
, after reporting higher-than-expected profit and sales.
Growth in its cloud computing division Amazon Web Services improved after slowing in recent quarters.
Apple's profit also beat Wall Street forecasts
, but iPhone sales missed expectations.
And the Australian-founded software firm
Atlassian's revenue came in ahead of estimates
, sending its shares up in extended trade.
We'll bring you more throughout the session so stay with us this Friday!
